content: Obesity has become one of the most important public health problems worldwide, which suggests the need for evidence-based dietary strategies for weight loss and its maintenance. Weight management depends upon complex factors such as amount of food eaten, type of food eaten, and timing of meals. In this review, we identified evidence-based dietary strategies for weight management based on these three components. An energy deficit is the most important factor in weight loss. A low-calorie diet with a low fat or carbohydrate content has been recommended; however, in some cases, a very-low-calorie diet is required for a short period. Some macronutrient composition-based diets, such as the ketogenic diet or high-protein diet, could be considered in some cases, although the potential risks and long-term effectiveness remain unknown. Meal timing is also an important factor in weight management, and higher-calorie breakfasts in combination with overnight fasting may help to prevent obesity. Our review indicated that there is no single best strategy for weight management. Hence, strategies for weight loss and its maintenance should be individualized, and healthcare providers must choose the best strategy based on patient preferences.

More than 650 million adults worldwide suffer from obesity, and the prevalence of this condition has increased rapidly during the past 50 years. Obesity has become one of the most important public health problems globally and is strongly associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM); cardiovascular diseases including myocardial infarction and stroke; osteoarthritis; obstructive sleep apnea; depression; and some types of cancer, such as breast, ovarian, prostate, liver, kidney, and colon cancer. Optimal diets for weight management have been a topic of debate not only among researchers, nutrition experts, and healthcare professionals, but also among the general public. According to a meta-analysis of several diet programs, calorie restriction was the primary driver of weight loss, followed by macronutrient composition. Another study examined the effects of popular diets without specific calorie targets and showed that the Atkins diet resulted in clinically meaningful weight loss after 6 months. In contrast, another review revealed that the Atkins, Weight Watchers, and Zone diets resulted in modest and similar long-term weight loss after 1 year. Recently, intermittent fasting and time-restricted eating have become popular and seem to be effective for weight loss. However, several questions remain unanswered. Does a high-protein diet aid in weight loss and maintenance? Can a ketogenic diet burn fat? Do carbohydrates increase abdominal fat? Can intermittent fasting help one lose weight? New dietary information has only added to the current confusion due to several controversial dietary regimens, and there is no clear guidance on the optimal diet for weight loss.

Obesity has become one of the most important public health problems worldwide, which suggests the need for evidence-based dietary strategies for weight loss and its maintenance. Weight management depends upon complex factors such as amount of food eaten, type of food eaten, and timing of meals. In this review, we identified evidence-based dietary strategies for weight management based on these three components. An energy deficit is the most important factor in weight loss. A low-calorie diet with a low fat or carbohydrate content has been recommended; however, in some cases, a very-low-calorie diet is required for a short period. Some macronutrient composition-based diets, such as the ketogenic diet or high-protein diet, could be considered in some cases, although the potential risks and long-term effectiveness remain unknown. Meal timing is also an important factor in weight management, and higher-calorie breakfasts in combination with overnight fasting may help to prevent obesity. Our review indicated that there is no single best strategy for weight management. Hence, strategies for weight loss and its maintenance should be individualized, and healthcare providers must choose the best strategy based on patient preferences.

Complex factors shape and influence diets, especially for weight management. However, amount of food eaten, type of food consumed (macronutrient composition), and meal timing of meals are the key components of weight-management strategies. In this review, we discuss several evidence-based dietary interventions for weight loss and weight-loss management based on these components. The key component of diets for weight loss and weight-loss maintenance is an energy deficit. Under the “calories-in, calories-out” model, dietary management has focused on the concept of “eat less, move more,” and patients have been advised to consider and calculate their calorie balance whenever they eat. However, energy intake and energy expenditure are dynamic processes influenced by body weight and influence each other. Thus, interventions aimed at creating an energy deficit through the diet are countered by physiological adaptations that resist weight loss.

A low-calorie diet involves consumption of 1,000–1,500 calories per day; deficits of 500–750 calories per day have been used for weight loss and are recommended by many obesity societies and guidelines. Low-calorie diets typically restrict fats or carbohydrates, neither of which has been determined to be more important for weight loss if only a calorie deficit occurs. The 2018 the Diet Intervention Examining The Factors Interacting with Treatment Success (DIETFITS) study found no significant differences in weight loss between low-fat and low-carbohydrate diets. However, meal planning and preparation take effort, and weight-loss maintenance requires a sustained low-calorie diet. Moreover, metabolic adaptations to decrease energy expenditure can lead to a plateau with this type of diet, which individuals may misinterpret as “failure” due to “lack of willpower.”

Traditionally, a very-low-calorie diet (VLCD), which provides < 800 kcal a day, is not recommended for routine weight management and should only be used in limited circumstances along with medical monitoring according to obesity guidelines. However, a recent review suggested that a VLCD used in combination with behavioral programs can provide greater long-term weight loss than behavioral programs alone, and that it is tolerable and has few adverse effects. Additionally, a VLCD with meal replacement is effective for achieving diabetes remission in individuals with obesity lasting for at least 2 years. Another form of the VLCD—the very-low-calorie ketogenic diet (VLCKD)—has been proposed as a promising option for significant weight loss in a short duration of time and stability for 2 years. The VLCKD consists of very-low-calorie (< 700–800 kcal/day) and low-carbohydrate (< 30–50 g/day) intake along with adequate protein consumption (equivalent to 0.8–1.2 g/day/kg of ideal body weight) for a short period, followed by a gradual switch to a low-calorie diet.

Meal replacements include not only products marketed as soups, shakes, and bars, but also portion-controlled, ready-made meals. Meal replacements are used instead of “normal” food for one or more meals to reduce the daily calorie intake. Meal replacements can be useful for calorie control because people tend to overestimate or underestimate the amount of calories in food. A systematic review showed the usefulness of meal replacement in weight loss, demonstrating a mean difference of –2.22 to –6.13 kg compared with other diets involving support alone. Despite their convenience and affordability, meal replacements are typically not successful for maintaining weight loss over a long duration. In summary, evidence shows that an energy deficit is the most important factor for weight loss, but metabolic adaptations to decrease energy intake can also lead to reduced energy expenditure. Therefore, long-term strategies for inducing an energy deficit are essential for effective weight management.

Long-term strategies for inducing an energy deficit are needed. If traditional low-calorie diet programs do not work or when there is a need for significant weight loss, a VLCD and meal replacement diets can be useful options. 

**Tags:** #EnergyDeficit #WeightLoss #VLCD #MealReplacement #DietStrategies

The strategy of reducing total fat intake is widely used for weight loss because a single gram of fat contains more calories than a gram of carbohydrates or protein. A low-fat diet usually consists of a dietary composition of fat ranging from very low (≤ 10% of calories from fat) to more moderate (≤ 30% of calories from fat and < 7%–10% from saturated fatty acids). However, randomized trials have failed to demonstrate better weight-loss maintenance by reducing energy intake from fat than other dietary interventions. The results of a meta-analysis did not support the use of low-fat diets over other dietary interventions for long-term weight loss. In another study, although low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level was reduced among individuals with obesity who followed a low-fat diet, triglyceride level increased and high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels decreased. Another review revealed that diets high in fat and saturated fatty acids could have unfavorable effects on the gut microbiota and are associated with an unhealthy metabolic state. Consuming large amounts of energy-dense foods with a high saturated fatty acid content can cause dysbiosis in the gut and is associated with obesity and low-grade chronic inflammation. Thus, diets low in saturated fatty acids, as well as those supplemented with good-quality fat and fibers, are a reliable and healthy strategy for people with obesity to achieve weight management and to prevent some types of cancer (including colorectal cancer and breast cancer) when combined with total calorie restriction.

**Tags:** #LowFatDiet #WeightLoss #Cholesterol #GutHealth #CancerPrevention

Although an energy deficit is the most important way to lose weight, weight regain after successful weight loss is very common and may seem inevitable. Thus, alternative dietary approaches for weight loss and its maintenance have become an area of interest among researchers and healthcare professionals. Low-carbohydrate (low-carb) diets have been widely used not only for weight reduction but also to manage T2DM; many randomized controlled trials have been conducted. A low-carb diet is defined as a carbohydrate intake below the lower boundary of the macronutrient distribution range for healthy adults (45%–65% of total daily energy) and encompasses a range of carbohydrate intake from 50–130 g/day or 10%–45% total energy from carbohydrates. With carbohydrate intake < 10% (or < 20–50 g/day), nutritional ketosis can occur; this type of diet is called a ketogenic diet. In this situation, daily protein intake is usually 0.8–1.5 g/kg of ideal body weight to preserve lean body mass. A systematic review and network meta-analysis that compared 14 dietary macronutrient patterns showed that most macronutrient diets resulted in modest weight loss over 6 months, but weight reduction and improvements in cardiometabolic factors largely disappeared after 12 months. A review of macronutrient pattern-based diets without specific calorie targets suggested that the Atkins diet, which involves low carbohydrate intake and high protein intake, was effective for clinically meaningful weight loss at 6 and 12 months post-initiation. Moreover, a recent review showed that the Mediterranean diet provided the strongest and most consistent benefits for both weight loss and improvement in cardiometabolic parameters. It should be noted that adequate protein intake is extremely important in calorie restriction for preservation of muscle mass regardless of diet.

**Tags:** #LowCarbohydrateDiet #WeightLoss #T2DM #KetogenicDiet #ProteinIntake

Ketogenic diet is characterized by an extreme reduction in carbohydrate intake (< 50 g/day) and a relative increase in the proportions of protein and fat. Ketogenic diets may decrease appetite and increase lipolysis, which may result in greater metabolic efficiency for fat consumption and can provide the same thermic effects as proteins. There are several types of carbohydrate-restricted diets, some of which limit carbohydrates to certain levels without restricting dietary protein and fat (such as the Atkins diet), whereas others allow moderate carbohydrate intake as well as moderate protein and fat intake. In one study, ketogenic diet showed mixed effects on LDL-C level and was not superior to other dietary interventions for weight loss. Ketogenic diet can suppress hunger during calorie restriction and may have some therapeutic effects on T2DM, polycystic ovary syndrome, and other metabolic disorders.

**Tags:** #KetogenicDiet #CarbohydrateRestriction #WeightLoss #MetabolicEfficiency #T2DM

Ketogenic diet can suppress hunger during calorie restriction and may have some therapeutic effects on T2DM, polycystic ovary syndrome, and cardiovascular and neurological diseases. However, more evidence is required to confirm its effectiveness and safety. Similar to VLCKDs, ketogenic diet is contraindicated in pregnant women; those with T1DM, kidney failure, or cardiac arrhythmia; and in older patients with frailty.  

Tags: #KetogenicDiet #HungerSuppression #T2DM #HealthRisks #WeightLoss

High-protein diet has been popularized as a promising tool for weight loss because it improves satiety and decreases fat mass. Dietary guidelines for adults recommend protein intake of 46–56 g or 0.8 g/kg of ideal body weight per day. Thus, if dietary protein consumption exceeds 0.8 g/kg/day, it is considered a high-protein diet. Usually, a high-protein diet refers to an increased protein intake to 30% of the total daily calories or 1–1.2 g/kg of the ideal body weight per day. The Atkins diet has gained popularity as a non-energy-restricting, low-carbohydrate, high-protein, and high-fat diet. In addition, diets high in protein with normal amounts of carbohydrates have been used to improve metabolic parameters. Diets with higher protein intake can provide significant benefits to prevent weight regain. A satiating effect is most significant with high-protein diets, and this effect helps decrease energy intake and maintain successful weight loss.  

Tags: #HighProteinDiet #WeightLoss #Satiety #AtkinsDiet #MetabolicHealth

The thermic effect of food, which is called diet-induced thermogenesis, is increased energy expenditure that results from nutrient processing; these values are highest for protein. Secretion of gut neuropeptides that induce satiation, such as glucagon-like peptide-1 or cholecystokinin, is increased in high-protein diets. These types of diets also may help preserve lean body mass during weight loss. A meta-analysis showed that protein supplementation can help preserve lean body mass in adults and older adults, although the effects on muscle strength and synthesis were less clear. Some studies have indicated that high intakes of protein and fat can increase the risk of T2DM. In addition, diets high in protein pose a potential risk to the kidneys due to their associated protein-induced acid loads, such as the sulfuric acid produced from oxidation of methionine and cysteine. High-protein diets do not adversely influence kidney function in healthy adults, though they are associated with increases in serum urea level and urinary calcium excretion, which might be related to a higher risk of kidney stone formation.  

Tags: #ThermicEffect #LeanBodyMass #KidneyHealth #ProteinIntake #T2DM

Protein from red meat consumption may increase the risk of chronic kidney disease; in contrast, low-fat dairy proteins, fish, and seafood do not have such an effect; proteins from fruits and vegetables actually might be renal protective. Considering that obesity is associated with chronic kidney disease and a high prevalence of subclinical chronic kidney disease, long-term high-protein intake, especially from animal sources, should be closely monitored in patients with obesity.  

Tags: #ChronicKidneyDisease #RedMeat #Obesity #DietaryProteins #HealthMonitoring

The Mediterranean diet involves high intake of fruits and vegetables, poultry, and fish and dairy products, and little to no consumption of red meat. The effectiveness of the Mediterranean diet for weight loss and preventing cardiovascular disease is supported by sufficient evidence. Its benefits may extend to the reduction in cancer risk and significant reduction in digestive cancer risk. Additionally, adherence to a Mediterranean diet may improve cognitive function and decrease the risk of dementia, although the evidence supporting this association is weak to moderate.  

Tags: #MediterraneanDiet #WeightLoss #CardiovascularHealth #CancerRisk #CognitiveFunction

One systematic review of the Mediterranean diet for long-term weight loss reported similar results to other diets despite greater weight loss than with a low-fat diet after 12 months. Despite this finding, a recent review reported that the Mediterranean diet showed the strongest evidence for weight loss and improvements in cardiometabolic parameters. The Mediterranean diet is food-based, nutrient adequate, and focused on vegetables, healthy fats, and fish; thus, it is a good strategy for maintaining long-term weight reduction. Low-fat and low-carbohydrate diets are good options for initial weight loss; in some cases, a ketogenic diet could be a viable alternative. High-protein diets may be effective in weight loss maintenance, and the Mediterranean diet not only helps with weight loss maintenance, but also aids in improving cardiovascular risk factors, cognitive functions, and mood.  

Tags: #LongTermWeightLoss #CardiometabolicHealth #DietStrategies #WeightMaintenance #HealthyEating

The Paleolithic (Paleo) diet is also known as the hunter-gatherer diet, caveman diet, primal diet, or Stone Age diet; all these diets suggest that our bodies have not evolved to handle highly processed foods. This diet follows the nutritional patterns of early humans.  

Tags: #PaleoDiet #HunterGatherer #NutritionalPatterns #ProcessedFoods #DietaryTrends

suggest that our bodies have not evolved to handle highly processed foods. This diet follows the nutritional patterns of early humans who lived in the Paleolithic era, which began more than 2 million years ago and continued until about 10,000 years ago, when humans started to cultivate plants and domesticate animals. Estimates are that our ancestors took in 35% of their calories from fat, 35% as carbohydrates (mostly fruits and vegetables), and 30% from protein. This diet advises consuming lean meat, fish, vegetables, fruits, and nuts while avoiding grains, dairy products, processed foods, and added sugar and salt. A review regarding the Paleo diet and its impact on cardiovascular risk factors suggested that it has favorable effects on lipid profile, blood pressure, and circulating C-reactive protein concentrations, but the evidence is not yet conclusive. The Paleo diet emphasizes vegetables and unprocessed foods, but it is also high in saturated fats, which might increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.

The glycemic index (GI) is a measurement system that ranks foods according to effect on blood glucose level; the rates at which different foods raise blood glucose level are ranked in comparison with absorption of 50 g of pure glucose as a reference (GI = 100). A low-GI diet emphasizes exchanging high-GI foods for low-GI alternatives. Nothing is strictly forbidden with the low-GI diet, but high-GI foods such as white bread, bagels, cereals, mashed potatoes, pasta, and noodles should be replaced by low-GI foods. The low-GI diet offers benefits in managing T2DM and decreasing body weight. However, one study found no differences in weight among low-GI diets and a diet based on healthy nutritional recommendations among overweight adolescent girls. The low-GI diet also does not provide a complete nutritional picture and does not include recommendations for daily intake of fat, protein, or fiber.

The new Nordic diet is based on unprocessed whole grains, high-fiber vegetables, fish, low-fat dairy foods, lean meat of all types (beef, pork, lamb), beans and lentils, fruit, dense breads, tofu, and skinless poultry. This diet recommends more calories from plant-based foods and emphasizes the consumption of local and seasonal ingredients. The Nordic diet is associated with various health benefits, including improved cardiovascular health, weight management, and reduced risk of chronic diseases. It encourages a balanced intake of macronutrients and promotes the use of healthy fats, such as those found in fish and nuts, while limiting processed foods and added sugars. Overall, the Nordic diet aligns with principles of sustainability and health, making it a favorable choice for those looking to improve their dietary habits.

The Nordic diet emphasizes consuming more foods from the sea, lakes, and wild countryside, while reducing meat intake. It is based on whole and minimally processed foods, rich in fiber and omega-3 fats. A systematic review indicated that adherence to the Nordic diet significantly improved body weight. However, accessibility and affordability of these food types may pose challenges for some individuals, making the diet difficult to maintain. 

Tags: Nordic diet, weight loss, whole foods, omega-3, accessibility

Adopting a vegetarian diet can be beneficial for health, as it lowers the risk of ischemic heart disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), and cancer. Vegetarian diets have been shown to reduce blood pressure, improve lipid profiles, and lower inflammatory biomarkers, as well as enhance glycemic control and other cardiometabolic risk factors. This diet excludes meat, fish, and poultry, but includes variations such as lactovegetarians and lacto-ovo-vegetarians. Dietary guidelines recommend vegetarian-patterned diets. A systematic review suggested that vegetarian diets can reduce mean body weight, although the studies are limited and of variable quality. However, since fish and seafood are excluded, this diet tends to be low in omega-3 fats. 

Tags: vegetarian diet, health benefits, cardiometabolic risk, glycemic control, omega-3

The Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet was developed to lower blood pressure without medication and is now recognized as one of the healthiest eating patterns. The DASH plan includes a variety of vegetables, fruits, and grains, with a focus on whole grains. It allows low-fat or non-fat dairy foods, pulses, nuts, seeds, lean meats, poultry, and seafood, while limiting sodium intake to 2,300 mg/day. The DASH diet has been shown to reduce the risk of cancer, cardiovascular risk factors, and both all-cause and cause-specific mortality. Additionally, it aids in weight loss, although the differences in weight loss are relatively small. 

Tags: DASH diet, blood pressure, healthy eating, weight loss, sodium intake

The Portfolio diet is a vegan plan that emphasizes a combination of foods or food components that lower cholesterol. When these foods are consumed together as part of a healthy diet, they are believed to lower LDL cholesterol (LDL-C) more effectively than any single food could alone. The diet recommends daily consumption of 2 g of plant sterols, 50 g of nuts, 10–25 g of soluble fibers from plant foods, and 50 g of soy protein, while excluding meat, poultry, seafood, dairy, and eggs. This diet has been shown to help reduce LDL-C, but its effects on weight loss are modest, ranging from -0.8 kg to -1.2 kg. 

Tags: Portfolio diet, vegan, cholesterol, LDL-C, weight loss

Intermittent fasting has gained attention from both medical experts and the general public interested in health. It involves regular periods of no or very limited calorie intake. The three most common regimens are alternate-day fasting, 5:2 intermittent fasting (where individuals fast or consume 900–1,000 calories for 2 days each week), and daily time-restricted feeding (fasting for 16–18 hours a day). The benefits of intermittent fasting stem not only from reduced calorie intake but also from its effects on metabolic switching, which can reverse insulin resistance, strengthen the immune system, and enhance physical and cognitive functions. Recent reviews suggest that intermittent fasting could be an effective weight-loss strategy for patients with obesity, comparable to daily calorie restriction. However, the long-term sustainability and health effects of this fasting method remain unclear. 

Tags: intermittent fasting, calorie intake, insulin resistance, weight loss, health benefits

Meal timing has recently garnered interest in relation to weight management, particularly concerning the circadian rhythm. Disruptions in circadian rhythms can lead to biochemical, physiological, and behavioral changes, often caused by factors such as exposure to artificial light at night, eating at night, or shifts in time due to jet lag or shift work. Understanding the impact of meal timing on weight management is an emerging area of research that may provide insights into effective dietary strategies. 

Tags: meal timing, circadian rhythm, weight management, dietary strategies, health

Eating late can cause circadian disruption, resulting in production of free cortisol, changes in daily rhythms of body temperature, decreased resting energy expenditure, and decreased glucose tolerance. Thus, timing of meals could have serious implications not only for weight management, but also for development of cardiovascular disease. A recent review confirmed that skipping breakfast increased the risk of overweight and obesity. Additionally, late-night eating was associated with obesity as well as metabolic syndrome. The American Heart Association recommends distributing calories over a defined period of the day, consuming a greater share of the total calorie intake earlier in the day, and maintaining consistent overnight fasting periods. Eating a high-calorie breakfast and overnight fasting could have positive effects on prevention of obesity, while intermittent fasting may help control calorie intake in people with obesity.

There is no single best strategy for weight management, although some evidence-based methods have been suggested. Reducing daily calorie intake is the most important factor for weight loss. Low-calorie recipes, especially those for low-fat or low-carbohydrate diets, have been suggested as the first dietary strategy, although in some cases, a very-low-calorie diet (VLCD) is required for a short period. Except for energy deficit, there seems to be no significant difference between macronutrient composition-based diets. Improvement in cardiometabolic factors strongly depends on the degree of weight loss. However, as in the Mediterranean diet, increasing consumption of fruits and vegetables and intake of healthy fats (including monounsaturated as well as polyunsaturated fats) can be a healthy strategy for weight loss and maintenance. Additionally, increased protein intake can help with weight loss maintenance.

Eating breakfast and avoiding late-night eating should be considered as part of a weight management strategy. Various dietary strategies for weight loss include low-calorie diets, very-low-calorie diets, meal replacements, low-fat diets, low-carbohydrate diets, ketogenic diets, high-protein diets, and the Mediterranean diet. Each of these strategies has its own recommendations regarding the amount of food intake and the type of food eaten. For instance, low-calorie diets typically involve consuming 1,000–1,500 calories with a deficit of 500–750 calories per day, while very-low-calorie diets involve 600–900 calories per day for a short period. Meal replacements can help control calories without much effort on calorie calculation or meal planning. The Mediterranean diet emphasizes high consumption of fruits and vegetables, poultry, fish, dairy products, and monounsaturated fats, which can improve cardiometabolic parameters and cognitive function.

Intermittent fasting is another effective weight-loss strategy, which includes alternate day fasting, 5:2 intermittent fasting, and daily time-restricted feeding. This approach involves fasting for 16–18 hours a day and has shown effectiveness in weight loss. Attention should be paid to patients currently being treated with hypoglycemic agents. Meal timing is also crucial; consuming a higher calorie breakfast and complying with overnight fasting can help prevent obesity. Overall, the combination of meal timing, dietary composition, and calorie control plays a significant role in effective weight management and obesity prevention.

Attention should be paid to patients currently being treated with hypoglycemic agents. Meal timing is crucial; consuming a higher calorie breakfast and complying with overnight fasting can help prevent obesity. Important dietary strategies not only focus on weight loss but also on metabolic health and are based on the physiologic clock. Time-restricted eating or intermittent fasting can be considered other options for weight loss and its maintenance. It is essential to maintain a low-calorie intake throughout an individual’s lifespan. Therefore, the best diet for weight management is one that can be sustained in the long term. Healthcare providers should consult with patients before choosing the optimal diet strategy because successful weight loss and its maintenance depend on the patient’s choices, preferences, and long-term adherence to the diet plan.

CONFLICTS OF INTEREST: Ju Young Kim is the Editorial Board member of the Journal of Obesity & Metabolic Syndrome. However, she is not involved in the peer reviewer selection, evaluation, or decision process of this article. Otherwise, no other potential conflicts of interest relevant to this article were reported.

In der Gewichtsreduktion ist die Ernährung ein entscheidender Faktor. Eine systematische Überprüfung und Meta-Analyse von randomisierten kontrollierten Studien hat gezeigt, dass verschiedene Diäten unterschiedliche Auswirkungen auf den Gewichtsverlust haben können. Insbesondere wurde festgestellt, dass eine kalorienreduzierte Ernährung, die auf eine moderate Fettaufnahme abzielt, effektiv sein kann. Die Ergebnisse deuten darauf hin, dass eine ausgewogene Zufuhr von Nährstoffen, einschließlich Fette, für die langfristige Gewichtskontrolle wichtig ist. Studien haben auch gezeigt, dass die Art der aufgenommenen Fette eine Rolle spielt, wobei gesunde Fette aus Nüssen, Samen und Fisch bevorzugt werden sollten. Die Berücksichtigung individueller Vorlieben und Lebensstile ist ebenfalls entscheidend für den Erfolg von Diäten. Tags: Gewichtsreduktion, Ernährung, Diäten, Fette, Nährstoffe

Die Rolle von Kohlenhydraten in der Ernährung ist ein weiteres wichtiges Thema. Eine Vielzahl von Studien hat die Auswirkungen von kohlenhydratarmen Diäten im Vergleich zu fettarmen Diäten auf den Gewichtsverlust und die metabolische Kontrolle untersucht. Insbesondere bei Menschen mit Typ-2-Diabetes wurde festgestellt, dass eine kohlenhydratarme Ernährung signifikante Vorteile bieten kann. Diese Diäten können helfen, den Blutzuckerspiegel zu stabilisieren und die Insulinempfindlichkeit zu verbessern. Es ist jedoch wichtig, die Qualität der Kohlenhydrate zu berücksichtigen, wobei Vollkornprodukte und ballaststoffreiche Lebensmittel bevorzugt werden sollten. Tags: Kohlenhydrate, Typ-2-Diabetes, metabolische Kontrolle, Blutzuckerspiegel, Insulinempfindlichkeit

Die Forschung hat auch gezeigt, dass die Mikrobiota des Darms eine wichtige Rolle bei der Gewichtsregulation und der allgemeinen Gesundheit spielt. Eine ausgewogene Ernährung, die reich an Ballaststoffen ist, kann das Wachstum gesunder Bakterien im Darm fördern. Studien haben gezeigt, dass eine Veränderung der Ernährung, insbesondere die Erhöhung der Ballaststoffaufnahme, positive Auswirkungen auf die Mikrobiota haben kann, was wiederum die Gewichtsreduktion unterstützen kann. Darüber hinaus gibt es Hinweise darauf, dass bestimmte Lebensmittel, wie fermentierte Produkte, die Gesundheit des Mikrobioms fördern können. Tags: Mikrobiota, Ballaststoffe, Gewichtsregulation, Darmgesundheit, Ernährung

Zusammenfassend lässt sich sagen, dass die Wahl der Diät und die Berücksichtigung individueller Bedürfnisse entscheidend für den Erfolg bei der Gewichtsreduktion sind. Es gibt keine universelle Lösung, und die besten Ergebnisse werden oft durch eine Kombination aus verschiedenen Ansätzen erzielt. Die Einbeziehung von Bewegung, die Anpassung der Kalorienzufuhr und die Berücksichtigung der persönlichen Vorlieben sind wichtige Faktoren, die in die Planung einer erfolgreichen Gewichtsmanagementstrategie einfließen sollten. Tags: Gewichtsmanagement, Diät, Bewegung, Kalorienzufuhr, persönliche Vorlieben

Low-carbohydrate and low-fat diets have been extensively studied for their effects on weight loss and maintenance in overweight and obese adults. A meta-analysis published in PLoS One in 2015 compared these two dietary approaches, highlighting the effectiveness of low-carbohydrate diets in achieving weight loss. The review by Kirkpatrick et al. in 2019 provided clinical recommendations on the management of body weight and cardiometabolic risk factors through low-carbohydrate and very-low-carbohydrate diets, including ketogenic diets. This scientific statement from the National Lipid Association emphasizes the importance of dietary choices in managing obesity and related health risks. Furthermore, a systematic review and network meta-analysis by Ge et al. in 2020 compared various dietary macronutrient patterns from popular diets, revealing their impact on weight and cardiovascular risk factors. Dinu et al. (2020) conducted an umbrella review of meta-analyses, assessing the effects of popular diets on anthropometric and cardiometabolic parameters, further supporting the role of diet in weight management. These studies collectively underscore the significance of dietary strategies in addressing obesity and improving health outcomes.

The therapeutic uses of very-low-carbohydrate diets, particularly ketogenic diets, have been reviewed by Paoli et al. in 2013, indicating their potential benefits beyond weight loss. This review discusses how such diets can be utilized for various health conditions, including metabolic disorders. Additionally, the appetite-suppressing effects of ketogenic diets were systematically reviewed by Gibson et al. in 2015, providing insights into their role in weight management. Halton and Hu (2004) critically reviewed the effects of high-protein diets on thermogenesis, satiety, and weight loss, suggesting that protein intake may play a crucial role in these processes. Berryman et al. (2018) analyzed protein intake trends in the United States, highlighting the importance of meeting dietary reference intakes for optimal health. The American Heart Association's Nutrition Committee, represented by St Jeor et al. (2001), emphasized the role of dietary protein in weight reduction, providing guidance for healthcare professionals. These findings collectively illustrate the multifaceted relationship between diet composition, particularly protein and carbohydrate intake, and weight management.

Dietary strategies for weight loss maintenance have been explored by van Baak and Mariman in 2019, emphasizing the need for sustainable approaches to prevent weight regain after initial loss. Westerterp (2004) discussed diet-induced thermogenesis, which refers to the energy expenditure associated with food intake, further contributing to our understanding of how diet affects metabolism. Research by Lejeune et al. (2006) examined the hormonal responses to high-protein diets, specifically ghrelin and glucagon-like peptide 1, and their implications for satiety and energy metabolism. Pasiakos et al. (2013) conducted a randomized controlled trial to assess the effects of high-protein diets on fat-free mass and muscle protein synthesis following weight loss, providing evidence for the benefits of protein in maintaining muscle during weight management. Wirth et al. (2020) performed a systematic review and meta-analysis on the role of protein intake and its timing on body composition and muscle function, reinforcing the importance of protein in dietary strategies for healthy adults. These studies highlight the critical role of dietary composition and timing in achieving and maintaining weight loss.

The impact of low-carbohydrate, high-protein, high-fat diets on the risk of type 2 diabetes has been investigated by Shan et al. in 2018, revealing that such diets may predict impending diabetes risk in certain populations. Reddy et al. (2002) studied the effects of low-carbohydrate high-protein diets on acid-base balance and calcium metabolism, indicating potential health implications of these dietary patterns. A systematic review and meta-analysis by Schwingshackl and Hoffmann in 2014 compared high versus normal/low protein diets on renal function in individuals without chronic kidney disease, providing insights into the safety of high-protein diets. Haring et al. (2017) explored dietary protein sources and their association with the risk of incident chronic kidney disease, emphasizing the need for careful consideration of protein sources in dietary planning. These findings contribute to the understanding of how different dietary patterns can influence metabolic health and the risk of chronic diseases, particularly in relation to protein and carbohydrate intake.

Die mediterrane Diät hat sich als vorteilhaft für die Gesundheit erwiesen, insbesondere in Bezug auf kardiovaskuläre Ergebnisse. Eine systematische Überprüfung und Meta-Analyse von Liyanage et al. (2016) zeigt, dass die mediterrane Diät positive Auswirkungen auf die kardiovaskuläre Gesundheit hat. Diese Diät, die reich an Obst, Gemüse, Vollkornprodukten, Nüssen und gesunden Fetten ist, fördert nicht nur die Gewichtsreduktion, sondern auch die allgemeine Gesundheit. Petersson und Philippou (2016) untersuchten den Zusammenhang zwischen der mediterranen Diät, kognitiven Funktionen und Demenz und fanden heraus, dass diese Ernährungsweise auch das Risiko für kognitive Beeinträchtigungen senken kann. Darüber hinaus zeigt eine systematische Überprüfung von Mancini et al. (2016), dass die mediterrane Diät langfristig zu Gewichtsverlust führen kann. Diese Ergebnisse unterstützen die Idee, dass die mediterrane Diät eine nachhaltige und gesunde Ernährungsoption darstellt, die sowohl das körperliche als auch das geistige Wohlbefinden fördert.

Die Auswirkungen von vegetarischen und veganen Diäten auf die Gesundheit sind ebenfalls gut dokumentiert. Eine systematische Überprüfung und Meta-Analyse von Dinu et al. (2017) zeigt, dass vegetarische und vegane Diäten mit mehreren gesundheitlichen Vorteilen verbunden sind, einschließlich einer verbesserten Gewichtsregulation und einem reduzierten Risiko für chronische Krankheiten. Lee et al. (2020) fanden heraus, dass vegetarische Diäten signifikant zur Senkung des Blutdrucks beitragen können. Darüber hinaus zeigen Wang et al. (2015), dass vegetarische Diäten positive Effekte auf die Blutfettwerte haben. Diese Studien belegen, dass pflanzliche Ernährungsweisen nicht nur gesund sind, sondern auch eine wichtige Rolle bei der Prävention von Herz-Kreislauf-Erkrankungen spielen können. Die Assoziation zwischen vegetarischer Ernährung und entzündlichen Biomarkern wurde von Haghighatdoost et al. (2017) untersucht, wobei festgestellt wurde, dass eine vegetarische Ernährung mit niedrigeren Entzündungswerten verbunden ist.

Die Forschung zu kohlenhydratarmen Diäten hat ebenfalls an Bedeutung gewonnen. Shai et al. (2008) untersuchten die Auswirkungen von kohlenhydratarmen, mediterranen und fettarmen Diäten auf den Gewichtsverlust und fanden heraus, dass alle drei Diäten effektiv sein können, jedoch unterschiedliche Auswirkungen auf die Gesundheit haben. Die Ergebnisse deuten darauf hin, dass eine kohlenhydratarme Ernährung nicht nur zur Gewichtsreduktion beiträgt, sondern auch positive Effekte auf metabolische Marker haben kann. Ko et al. (2020) analysierten die Auswirkungen von proteinreichen Diäten auf die Nierengesundheit und die Langlebigkeit und kamen zu dem Schluss, dass eine ausgewogene Zufuhr von Protein wichtig ist, um die Nierenfunktion zu unterstützen. Diese Erkenntnisse sind entscheidend für die Entwicklung von Diätstrategien, die sowohl Gewichtsmanagement als auch die Erhaltung der Nierengesundheit fördern.

Vegetarian diets have gained significant attention in recent years, with various studies examining their impact on health and weight management. A systematic review and meta-analysis conducted by Barnard et al. (2015) highlighted the changes in body weight associated with vegetarian diets, indicating that such dietary patterns can lead to weight loss and improved health outcomes. Furthermore, the DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) diet has been extensively studied for its effects on blood pressure and overall cardiovascular health. Research by Filippou et al. (2020) and Siervo et al. (2015) demonstrated that adherence to the DASH diet can significantly reduce blood pressure in both hypertensive and non-hypertensive adults. This dietary approach not only aids in hypertension management but also contributes to weight loss and improved body composition, as shown in studies by Soltani et al. (2016). Overall, these findings suggest that both vegetarian and DASH diets are effective strategies for promoting health and preventing chronic diseases. 

Tags: vegetarian diets, weight management, DASH diet, blood pressure, cardiovascular health.

Intermittent fasting has emerged as a popular dietary strategy for weight loss and health improvement. Research by de Cabo and Mattson (2019) discusses the effects of intermittent fasting on health, aging, and disease, suggesting that this eating pattern may have beneficial effects on metabolic health. A systematic review by Welton et al. (2020) further supports the efficacy of intermittent fasting for weight loss, indicating that it can lead to significant reductions in body weight and fat mass. Additionally, the timing of meals has been shown to influence metabolic processes. Studies by Lopez-Minguez et al. (2016) and Bandín et al. (2015) reveal that meal timing can affect glucose tolerance and substrate oxidation, which are crucial for maintaining a healthy weight and preventing obesity. These findings underscore the importance of not only what we eat but also when we eat, highlighting the potential of meal timing as a strategy for weight management and metabolic health. 

Tags: intermittent fasting, weight loss, meal timing, metabolic health, obesity.

Eating habits play a critical role in managing health, particularly in relation to obesity and diabetes. A systematic review by Ma et al. (2020) found that skipping breakfast is associated with an increased risk of overweight and obesity, emphasizing the importance of regular meal consumption for weight management. Additionally, Gouda et al. (2018) explored the associations between eating habits and glycemic control in Japanese workers with type 2 diabetes, revealing that certain dietary patterns can significantly impact blood sugar levels and overall health. The American Heart Association has also recognized the implications of meal timing and frequency for cardiovascular disease prevention, as outlined in a scientific statement by St-Onge et al. (2017). These studies collectively highlight the significance of mindful eating practices and regular meal patterns in promoting health and preventing chronic diseases such as obesity and diabetes. 

Tags: eating habits, obesity, diabetes, glycemic control, cardiovascular health.
